Background on the Fisher Information

Chemical Reaction Networks

We consider Chemical Reaction Networks as Markov pure jump processes (see [AK15]).

We introduce \((X_t)_{t \in \mathbb{R}_+}\) the distribution of the jump process.

In the same setting as introduced in [CTS23b], \(X_t\) has a probability mass function \(p_t^\theta\), whose evaluation at the point \(x \in \mathbb{N}^N\) we write \(p(x; t, \theta)\). We also introduce the likelihood \(p : \mathbb{N}^N \times \mathbb{R}_+ \times \mathbb{R}_+^M \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_+\).

Approximation of the mass function and the sensitivity of the likelihood

If the state-space of \(X_t\) is finite, it can be projected into a finite subset of \(\mathbb{N}\) whose cardinality will be written \(N_{\max} \in \mathbb{N}^*\). We will write the ordered elements of the projected state-space as \(\big\{x^1_t, x^2_t, ..., x^{N_{\max}}_t \big\}\).

For ease of notation, we introduce :

\[p_i(t,\theta)=p(x^i;t,\theta) \quad \forall i \in [\![1, N_{\max}]\!]\]

We then define the sensitivity \(S^\theta_t \in \mathcal{M}_{N_{\max},M}(\mathbb{R})\) of the likelihood of \(X_t\) as:

\[\big[S_t^\theta\big]_{ij} = \frac{\partial p_i}{\partial \theta_j}(t, \theta)\]

Fisher Information of sampled Chemical Reaction Networks

Let us define the Fisher Information \(\mathcal{I}_t^\theta \in \mathcal{M}_{M, M}(\mathbb{R})\) of \(X_t\) as [FM19]:

\[\mathcal{I}_t^\theta = E_{\theta}\Big[ \big(\nabla_{\theta} \log p(X_t; t,\theta)\big)^\top\big(\nabla_{\theta} \log p(X_t; t,\theta)\big)\Big]\]

If the state-space of \(X_t\) is finite`, \(\mathcal{I}_t^\theta\) can be rewritten as:

\[\mathcal{I}_t^\theta = \big[ S_t^\theta \big]^\top \text{Diag}\Big(\frac{1}{p_t^\theta}\Big)S_t^\theta\]

Specific details can be found in the article [CTS23b].

Both the Deep Learning and Finite State Projection methods use this formula to estimate the Fisher Information for sampled Chemical Reaction Networks.
